page.title: 02RUSHALL HALL/PARK LIME PITS
page.content: {Rushall}came from the{Anglo-Saxon}name {Ryschale}meaning Rush Hall. The walls around Rushall Hall are made of {limestone}and{sandstone. The Park Lime {Pits}lake, near the Hall, was a limestone working that caved in, flooded and formed the present lake. Above the gates of the Hall there is the coat of arms of the{Harpur}family. The first Hall on the present site was built in the{12th Century}from sandstone. Many surrounding roads were named after the families who once lived at Rushall Hall such as{Leigh, {Mellish}and{Buchanan. Prince Rupert captured the Hall during the{Civil {War.}It is possible to find cannon balls from the seige. Next to Rushall Hall is{Rushall Parish Church}that holds its annual garden party in the grounds of the Hall.
